body: It was the first Saturday of the month. A throbbing beat washed over the Omni, a cavernous nightclub in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. Big Brother D, a jut-jawed rapper, strutted across the stage, mike in hand. ''Feel the Holy Ghost vibe,'' he urged the audience, most of whom were black and in their 20's. ''If you have a problem and no one else can
title: Taking Back the Nightclub; Gospel Spots Offer Entertainment With a Christian Flavor

author: Kenneth T. Jackson, a professor of history at Columbia University, is the author of ''Crabgrass Frontier'' and the editor of ''The Encyclopedia of New York City.''
body: A century ago New Yorkers celebrated New Year's Eve with special exuberance. Dec. 31, 1997, was filled with speeches, parades, fireworks, brass bands and the reading of a commissioned ''Ode to Greater New York.'' At midnight, illuminated by the glow of 500 magnesium lights, thousands of people gathered in front of City Hall (there was as yet no
title: 100 Years Of Being Really Big

body: After a night of heavy drinking, six New York City undercover narcotics detectives savagely kicked a Brooklyn man in his face and ribs outside a Crown Heights nightclub, dragged him along the sidewalk by his ankle and fired at him as he fled, a witness said yesterday. The man, Reginald Bannerman, 35, a gym teacher, died less than two hours later,
title: Witness Says Police Detectives Beat a Man Who Later Died

body: LINCOLN CENTER From Ushers to Ballerinas, Artistry Created Off Stage Many of the costume makers, ushers, security guards, electricians and ballet dancers at Lincoln Center have second lives, as painters, sculptors, sketchers and the like. title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Six New York City police detectives have been suspended for failing to report their role in a Brooklyn bar brawl last week with a man who died beneath a subway train less than two hours later, the police said. The man, Reginald Bannerman, 35, was killed by a Manhattan-bound No. 2 train in the Sterling Street station about 1:30 A.M. on Dec. 19. His
title: 6 Detectives Suspended Over Roles In Bar Brawl

body: It might seem odd to think of long baggy shorts as rebel wear. But when the National Basketball Association fined the Minnesota Timberwolves and the Portland Trail Blazers $25,000 each last month after seven players wore shorts deemed too long, the cool quotient for below-the-knee hemlines rose a notch. title: PULSE; Too Low to Go

body: With guided tours and scheduled stops along Manhattan's major traffic routes, tour buses have become a popular way for tourists to visit the borough's many attractions, like the Empire State Building, the World Trade Center and Harlem churches. And soon, double-decker tour buses may also be prowling the streets of Brooklyn, offering stops to enjoy
title: Hopping Off Soon in Brooklyn: Tours by Double-Decker Bus

body: Edna Flannery Kelly, the first woman to represent Brooklyn in Congress and an expert in foreign affairs and social policy, died on Sunday at the home of her daughter in Alexandria, Va. She was 91. A lifelong New Yorker, she had moved to Alexandria in 1982 following a stroke. Mrs. Kelly, who had cancer, experienced another stroke shortly before her
title: Edna Kelly, Congresswoman From Brooklyn, Is Dead at 91

body: Eight people, including a 14-year-old girl and a 15-year-old boy, were arrested at an apartment in Coney Island, Brooklyn, yesterday, after a teen-age girl told the police that they had held her captive there for nearly a week, beating her and burning her with a clothes iron. The authorities said they were unsure what motivated the reported
title: Eight Arrested in the Imprisonment and Beating of a Girl, 15

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Scenes from the Malls: Megastores and Mini-Bazaars

body: Shirley Seaton has never shied away from hard work. Soon after arriving in New York from the Caribbean island of St. Vincent in 1976, she cobbled together a living as a housekeeper, commuting to the homes of the wealthy in New Jersey and on Long Island. When she obtained her green card a few years later, she found work as a home-care attendant,
title: The Neediest Cases; After Going Blind, Mother Worries Most About Son's Future

body: Houston is no longer the largest city in the nation never to have elected a black mayor, and the victor in Saturday's election here, Lee Patrick Brown, took note of that racial milestone in a speech late Saturday night to a cheering throng of supporters in a hotel near the Astrodome. ''My friends,'' said the 60-year-old Mayor-elect, ''another
title: Houston Elects Lee Brown As Its First Black Mayor

body: AT the corner of Dean Street and Brooklyn Avenue in Crown Heights, the 50-room John and Elizabeth Truslow house stands tribute to the days when this was one of Brooklyn's finest neighborhoods. But the house, built in 1887 for a businessman and philanthropist who was a member of a prominent Brooklyn family, has seen finer days. It was long ago
title: Habitats/96 Brooklyn Avenue, Crown Heights; A Landmark Facade, A Troubled Interior

body: Lee Patrick Brown, who grew up on a farm in small-town Oklahoma and headed police forces in three of the biggest cities in the nation, was elected Mayor of Houston tonight, becoming the first member of a racial minority to be Mayor in the city's history. Mr. Brown, who is black, overcame a barrage of negative television advertising by his opponent,
title: Brown Wins Mayoral Race In Houston

body: WHAT POSSESSED Anna Deavere Smith, the ingenious theater performer who mines verbatim monologues from life, to imagine drama could be found in the utterances of this city's political stock company of hopelessly self-referential performers? They chew the scenery for breakfast here. Even the spear carriers in the news media fancy themselves in star
title: THEATER; Where Performers Fill Every Seat in the House

title: HOUSTON'S VOTERS HEAR FROM GIULIANI

title: A Wedding Of Theater And Social Issues

title: How To Fight City Hall

body: Despite the specter of gang-related mayhem that kept thousands of children away from classes on Friday, city officials said yesterday that there were no incidents of gang violence in any of the five boroughs on Halloween. title: Halloween Was the Safest In Decades, Officials Say

body: Music and Magic For Halloween Mysterious appearances and disappearances are Halloween's signature, so it's no surprise that they will be part of the program tomorrow at the Little Orchestra Society's Happy Concert for Young People. For one thing, the narrator, Robert Cuccioli, has considerable experience in the area: he's now playing Jekyll and
title: Family Fare

body: Nushawn J. Williams, a Brooklyn neighbor put it with plain-spoken certainty, was ''running wild from Day 1.'' And Mr. Williams's sprint into trouble -- from a broken home to childhood thievery, from gangs to crack dens, from girl to girl -- has left a breathtaking array of damage, recounted by former neighbors, acquaintances and the authorities.
title: After Childhood of Violence, A One-Man H.I.V. Epidemic

body: There is always a current of amazement when Mayor Rudolph W. title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE MAYORAL RACE; Giuliani, in Harlem, and Messinger, in Brownsville, Court Black Voters

body: Follow Flatbush Avenue in Brooklyn with enough persistence, and eventually you wind up at Floyd Bennett Field. This is the end of the line, an abandoned airport where the wind swirls and whips, disturbing the ghosts of Amelia Earhart, Howard Hughes and Wiley Post, the fliers who helped make Floyd Bennett Field a symbol of the romance of aviation.
title: >New York And Its Wealth Of Nature (Really!)

title: Brooklyn Mother Is Charged With Strangling Her Daughter, 3

title: Judge Denies Sharpton Bid For Runoff

title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK CITY; 2 Arrested in Shooting Of Officer in Traffic Jam

Giuliani and three of the Democratic mayoral candidates joined thousands of celebrators in a march down Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn yesterday as this year's mayoral contest lent a political tone to one of New York City's largest and most exuberant ethnic celebrations:
title: Parade Is Stumping Ground for Mayoral Candidates

title: 3 Democrats for Mayor Continue to Campaign on Police Abuse

body: Rene Gross of Flatbush has seen a few county fairs in her day, but never one with a kosher concession stand. But there they were yesterday: Mrs. Gross pushing a stroller over an old runway at Floyd
title: Deep in the Heart of Brooklyn, Cowboys and Kosher Food

title: Admirers Pay Respects With Tears And Flowers

title: Mood Turning Political For West Indian Parade

title: Facing Storm of Rage, Officers Are Impassive

body: When rioting broke out in Los Angeles in 1992, Bill Clinton, in the midst of a struggling campaign for the White House, flew to the West Coast and toured the ruins of South-Central Los Angeles. He then returned on an overnight flight to New York for a speech in which he laid the blame for the racial disorder on Republican ''denial and neglect.''

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's new task force on police and community relations was designed as a forum for disagreement, bringing together 29 New Yorkers of wildly divergent views on one of the most volatile issues in the city. title: Where Has Your Neighborhood Drug Dealer Gone?

title: Guard Finds Baby At Brooklyn Hospital

title: Opening A Window On Hasidism

body: A teacher at a public elementary school in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday, accused of having kissed and reached under the skirt of a sixth grader in his classroom on Monday, investigators for the Board of Education said. The teacher, Roland L. Pierre, 62, of Public School 138 in Crown Heights, was charged with sexual abuse and endangering the
title: Brooklyn Teacher Is Charged With Sexual Abuse

body: A fast-moving line of thunderstorms raced across the metropolitan area yesterday afternoon and evening, causing minor damage and flooding, but major aggravation, particularly in Westchester County. Besides toppling trees and downing power lines, high winds from the storms injured one person in Rye, N.Y., and briefly blacked out some parts of the
title: Storms Bring Delays and Downed Trees

body: SHABAZZ-Dr. Betty. Columbia University mourns the passing of our friend and colleague, Dr. Betty Shabazz. Dr. Shabazz devoted her life to promoting the values of education, community, and family. She was herself a leading example of those principles, educating herself in college and graduate school while working and raising a family following the
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SHABAZZ, DR. BETTY

body: When the State Education Commissioner, Richard P. Mills, proposed an ambitious new rule last year that would require all high school students to pass a battery of college-preparatory Regents tests, few imagined that Victoria Strong, a teen-ager from East New York in Brooklyn, and her fellow ninth graders at Fashion Industries High School would
title: State's Stiffer Standards for Graduation Are Embraced by Many in Class of 2000

body: ''If you're a writer,'' the scraggly-bearded scholar said, glowering at a reporter trying to enter his yeshiva, ''look elsewhere for a story.'' Like many others in the close-knit community of Bobover Hasidim, the scholar was angry that newspaper and television reporters should stream into Brooklyn's Borough Park simply because two local residents
title: Drug Arrests Give a Jolt To a Sect Of Hasidim

body: Living with her aunt in a rent-stabilized apartment in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, has become just about untenable for Sheria G. McFadden, 29. She has a new baby and job at City College in Harlem, more than an hour's commute away by subway. She needs to move. Under the Republican proposal to remove rent regulations from apartments when they become
title: Although Meant to Create Fluidity, Decontrol Could Freeze the Market

body: THE noble calling of putting other people's troubles on your own shoulders has suffered serious blows with the vicious killing of Jonathan Levin. He got involved, this rich young man who taught at a Bronx high school and went out of his way to get to know his poor students. What it got him is dead, or so many New Yorkers are thinking now that the
title: Get Involved? No Alternative For Teachers

body: THIS year the Brooklyn Museum of Art turns 175 years old and its present building turns 100. The Cyclone roller coaster turns 70 and the Welcome Back to Brooklyn Festival turns 15. Coming home to their native Brooklyn are this year's Homecoming King and Queen, Lainie Kazan, the actress, who grew up in Flatbush and graduated from Erasmus Hall High
title: Brooklyn Birthdays Merit a Coronation

body: A 15-year-old boy fell four stories to his death in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, yesterday evening when he tried jumping from one rooftop to another, apparently to escape four dogs that were chasing him, the police said. The boy, Richard Collingwood, had been playing with friends on the roof of 1160 President Street, about four blocks from his home,
title: Boy Falls to His Death Jumping Roof to Roof

body: A study commissioned by New York City has found that allowing rent increases once an apartment falls vacant, a policy recommended by Gov. George E. Pataki, would have a limited impact on the rent of most apartments during the next two years. But a few areas, including the Upper West Side, would see rent increases as high as 30 percent, the study
title: Rent Decontrol Study: From No Impact to 30% Increases

body: Dr. Vernal G. Cave, a Brooklyn physician and civic leader whose series of imposing titles tended more to obscure than to reflect his almost half-century of quiet, day-to-day work on behalf of black medical, political and social causes, died on Wednesday at University Hospital of Brooklyn. He was 78 and had been a founding director of both the New
title: Dr. Vernal G. Cave, 78, Dies; Led in Medical and Civic Issues

title: At Monastery In Brooklyn, An Era Ends

title: Celebration Stirs Up Memories in Stands

body: For a decade, city officials have boasted that nearly three-quarters of New York's streets were acceptably clean. In February, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani released the city's latest self-evaluation, a survey that said 83 percent of the streets were clean -- a remarkable figure considering substantial cuts in the Sanitation Department's budget in
title: A Review Finds the City Dirtier Than It Says It Is

body: IT goes without saying that they will remember Jack Roosevelt Robinson today at Middle School 320 in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. title: Needing More Than a Dodger Over the Door

body: CONFRONTED with some of the most pressing problems of public education, city school officials in recent years have turned to community groups to help resuscitate failing schools, teach music and arts, and rehabilitate the most troubled youngsters. But the efforts of two community groups to seize the initiative and create new schools in Brooklyn and
title: Hard Lessons in Creating a School

Make the speech inspiring, he was asked, something to encourage a group of children whose universe is one of New York City's most
title: Celebrity Visits Show What's Missing in City Schools

body: Shattering the peace that has enveloped the Democratic mayoral contest until now, Ruth W. Messinger condemned the Rev. Al Sharpton yesterday for saying he did not consider Louis Farrakhan an anti-Semite, asserting that such words would ''only serve to tear us apart.'' Ms. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, made the remark to Mr. Sharpton
title: Messinger Lashes Out At Sharpton

body: IT looked as though there were a thousand Lego pieces on the floor of the Cohen family's living room in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, last Sunday afternoon -- and each one was about to get a bath. For Rabbi Eli Cohen and his wife, Yehudis, who are Lubavitcher Hasidic Jews, spring means Passover, and Passover means an Olympic-caliber cleaning operation.
title: Passover Rituals, Lovingly Applied

body: THE words ''Jackie Robinson School'' are above the brick doorway. To the side, his face dominates a mural that 1,400 students, grades six to eight, pass on their way in and out. Under a blue cap with a white B, his face is surrounded by the words ''athlete father friend leader winner humanitarian pioneer businessman.'' To the right, he's swinging a
title: Robinson 'Stood Up For What He Believed'

body: A manhunt for a serial rapist who had been plaguing two Brooklyn neighborhoods apparently paid off on Sunday night, when a team of police officers staking out one of his previous targets arrested a suspect after chasing him across rooftops and down a fire escape, the police said yesterday. The suspect, Mark Fergus, 24, was arrested in at least
title: Suspect in Serial Rapes Is Arrested

title: 4,000 Hearts Full of Hope Line Up for 700 Jobs

body: Joseph Harold Haynes, a supervising subway engineer whose curiosity and keen eye helped him find the remnants of a 19th-century black settlement hidden in a Brooklyn alley, died on March 2 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 66 and lived in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. The cause was cancer, said Joan Maynard, executive director of the
title: Joseph Haynes, 66; Found Old Black Settlement

body: A serial rapist who wears a mask, climbs up fire escapes and breaks through bedroom windows struck again on Monday night in Brooklyn, the police said. Saying that they consider the man responsible for seven sexual attacks and seven separate burglaries in the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Crown Heights and Kensington, the police offered an $11,000
title: Police Seek Serial Rapist In Brooklyn

body: IN Detroit, Keely Robinson's parents lived in private homes, and she grew up in two of them, both in middle-class neighborhoods. Kenneth Walker has owned houses both in Toronto and the Caribbean island of Jamaica. Jason Pascal's father was a taxi driver in Trinidad and owned his own house. ''My family never paid rent,'' Mr. Pascal said. The common
title: How 'Equity Leases' Became a Track to Ownership

body: For New York City, 1968 was an annus horribilis like no other. Most poor neighborhoods were angry and volatile after the murder of the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. The assassination of Senator Robert Kennedy broke the city's heart. Columbia University and other campuses were paralyzed by turmoil. Then came the 55-day teachers' strike, an event so
title: A City at War

body: SIMILAR in some ways to Mardi Gras in New Orleans or Carnival in Rio de Janeiro, Rara is a Haitian festival, held between Ash Wednesday and Good Friday that features richly rhythmic music, parades and vibrant costumes. Rara will visit the Brooklyn Children's Museum today, with a performance by a master drummer, Frisner Augustin; and La Troupe
title: A Haitian Celebration, With Drums and Bells

body: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract. body: To the Editor: After reading ''The Hustling Life,'' I am so tired of your paper paying writers to glamorize hustlers, especially the black ones. Yes, it's not a black-white issue, but those stories are so boring after a while. And for those of us who work and live with young black men, it's always sad to see those stories. I think this is what our
title: Portrait of a Hustler Refutes Illusion of Glamour

body: A 29-year-old man with a lengthy criminal record and a history of parole violations was arrested and charged with breaking into several brownstones in Brooklyn and attacking at least four people who were at home when he struck, the police said yesterday. The man, Derrick Williams, was arrested Monday night after he tried to break into a building on
title: Man Is Linked to 8 Crown Hts. Burglaries

body: To the Editor: The conviction of Lemrick Nelson Jr. and Charles Price in Federal court for depriving Yankel Rosenbaum of his civil rights -- and of his life -- in the 1991 civil disturbances in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was a victory for the truth. Your Feb. 11 editorial ignores the facts in a display of high-minded balance. Plainly put, the
title: Crown Heights Verdict Was Victory for Truth

body: Five and a half years after racial violence rocked Crown Heights in Brooklyn, with shock waves felt in Washington, two black men were convicted last Monday in the stabbing death of a Hasidic Jew attacked during the outbreak. The men, Lemrick Nelson Jr., 21, and Charles Price, 43, were found guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn of violating
title: A New Verdict in Crown Heights

body: As the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York, Zachary W. Carter commands more than 150 prosecutors handling hundreds of cases from three New York City boroughs and Long Island. But in recent weeks, Mr. Carter, 46, has appeared consumed by a single case. It was a case that originated in the small Brooklyn neighborhood of Crown
title: A Prosecutor-Manager, Tested by Crown Hts.

body: The writers of The Village Voice knew their alternative world was changing yet again when their new leader gave them an introductory pep talk by quoting a favorite, now-dead editor of The New York Post. ''He once told me, 'Lemme tell you something, kid,' '' the new Voice editor recounted to his staff. '' 'You gotta grab the reader by the throat.
title: New Editor Changes the Cadence of The Village Voice

body: A day after two black men were convicted in the killing of a Hasidic Jew during the 1991 racial violence in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, their lawyers began planning appeals yesterday that will include the argument that putting both men on trial together harmed each man's case. The defense teams for Lemrick Nelson Jr. and Charles Price, who were found
title: Lawyers for 2 Start Planning Appeals of Convictions in Crown Heights Killing

body: The Rev. Al Sharpton found yesterday, as he spoke on talk radio, that there was more interest in his run for Mayor than in the Crown Heights verdicts. Black people in Jamaica, Queens, gave blank stares when asked about the case. Hovering helicopters and beat-up cars with undercover police officers riding around Brooklyn never went into action. Five
title: Aches Remain, but Few Have Anger Left

body: Five years ago, when Lemrick Nelson Jr. went to dinner with Brooklyn jurors to celebrate his acquittal for the murder of a Hasidic Jew during the Crown Heights violence, he had no way of knowing the verdict was, in essence, temporary. Yesterday, a Federal jury convicted Mr. Nelson on a related charge for the same incident, largely because Federal
title: Learning From a Loss

body: Two black men were convicted yesterday in the death of a Hasidic Jew in the 1991 violence that shook Crown Heights, Brooklyn, and laid bare once again New York's deep racial divide. One of the men, Lemrick Nelson Jr., had been acquitted in 1992 of state murder charges in the fatal stabbing. That verdict caused an outcry in the tight-knit Hasidic
title: 2 Guilty in Fatal Crown Hts. Violence

body: Yesterday's Federal jury verdict finding Lemrick Nelson Jr. and another defendant, Charles Price, guilty for their roles in the 1991 slaying of Yankel Rosenbaum, during a night of mob violence in Brooklyn's Crown Heights neighborhood, provides a reasoned legal ending to a long ordeal for the city and those involved in the case. It also vindicates
title: A Second Crown Heights Verdict

body: MOMENTS after the guilty verdicts were announced yesterday in Crown Heights II, an architect of the troubled first Crown Heights trial picked up the phone and asked to be put through to Janet Reno, the United States Attorney General. ''I called to tell her how grateful I was that she listened to us and agreed that this case was worth pursuing,''
title: A 2d Verdict, And Thoughts Of Last Time

title: NEWS SUMMARY

title: A Car Crash, a Disturbance, the Aftermath

body: One of the most agonizing parts of any trial -- for the defendants and the families of victims of violent crime -- is the gut-wrenching time when the testimony is over, the voices of witnesses and lawyers are stilled, and the 12 citizens who make up the jury disappear into the recesses of the courthouse to weigh it all. So it is in Federal District
title: Views From 3 Sides Of a Courtroom Vigil

body: OK., maybe O. J. is half-guilty. What else is a person supposed to conclude? One unanimous jury said he was not guilty. But last week, a second jury, also unanimous, said in essence that he was. Welcome to the mixed messages of Justice Redux, the era of sequels, remakes and rematches. Last year brought Menendez II and Goetz II; 1997 is off to a
title: Tried and Tried Again, With a Vengeance

body: A Federal jury in Brooklyn deliberated for a third day yesterday without reaching a verdict in the case of Lemrick Nelson Jr., 21, and Charles Price, 43, two black men charged with violating the civil rights of Yankel Rosenbaum, a Hasidic Jew who was fatally stabbed during the Crown Heights racial violence of 1991. Deliberations will resume on
title: No Crown Heights Decision

body: SCOTT FITZGERALD got it wrong when he wrote that ''there are no second acts in American lives,'' but don't blame him. He didn't live long enough to witness American jurisprudence in the 1990's, with celebrated trials continually getting a second life. We have had Rodney King I and II, Bernhard H. Goetz I and II, and of course O. J. Simpson I and
title: Trial Reruns May Heighten Polarization

body: Even before they began deliberating yesterday, the jurors in the Crown Heights trial made clear their sensitivity to the racial implications of the bitterly controversial case, raising questions about whether one of the black or Jewish members of the jury should lead it. Barely 40 minutes after receiving the case of two black men charged with
title: Crown Hts. Jury Asks Judge About Forewoman Choice

body: Lawyers for two black men charged in the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic Jew during the 1991 racial violence in Crown Heights yesterday attacked the motives of the police and prosecutors, questioned the testimony of important witnesses and asserted that the defendants were scapegoats in the politically charged case. Summing up their cases in a packed
title: Crown Hts. Civil Rights Trial Is Set to Go to Jury Today

body: In a theatrical finale to the defense's case, the man accused in the fatal stabbing of a Hasidic Jew in the Crown Heights racial violence paced before a Brooklyn jury yesterday in the baggy jeans the authorities say he wore during the attack, only to have the pants slide down below his knees. The defense hopes the demonstration will convince jurors
title: Baggy Jeans Are Last Issue In Rights Trial

body: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Allies Freeze Distribution Of Confiscated Nazi Gold The United States, Britain and France have agreed to freeze the distribution of gold bars looted by Nazi troops but then confiscated by the Allied powers at the end of World War II. Jewish groups have claimed that some of the gold came from Jews whose assets had been seized as
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: When the racially charged Crown Heights case first went to trial in 1992, the state court jury was made up only of Brooklyn residents, six of whom were black, and there were no Jews on the panel. This time, the case is in Federal court before a more diverse panel, with residents of three boroughs and Long Island. There are two Jews on the jury and
title: This Time, Diversity In Crown Heights Jury

body: Major Developments: News Summaries, Page A2 NEW YORK In Schools, a Vanishing Breed In the vastness of the New York City public school system, former police officers have slipped into an unusual niche as teachers. They frequently work in schools in battered neighborhoods that other teachers shun. And instead of becoming stereotypes of the
title: METRO DIGEST

body: A prominent group of black elected officials held a forum yesterday on the next mayoral race, but the potential candidate that almost everyone was talking about was thousands of miles away. The Council of Black Elected Democrats met in midtown to question four candidates for the Democratic nomination for mayor on a wide range of topics. Yet there
title: Dinkins, From Afar, Is Talk of Forum

''It is our belief,'' said a lawyer for Mr. Nelson,
title: Lawyers Say Bloody Pants Will Not Fit A Defendant

body: The judge in the Crown Heights trial strongly suggested last night that he would not accept a guilty verdict for one of the two defendants who is accused of inciting the attack on a Hasidic man, unless the jurors concluded that the man was actually present at the fatal stabbing. During the trial, prosecutors did not present any witnesses who
title: Judge Suggests He Might Deny Guilty Verdict

title: Insisting Giuliani Can Be Beaten, Dinkins Weighs Entering the Race

title: The Rainbow Finds a Voice That Rarely Speaks of Itself

title: Friend of Crown Heights Suspect Says He Confessed

title: News Summary

body: When a friend gave Luis Vettorazzi a video camera to use on vacation in 1991, Mr. Vettorazzi, then a building superintendent in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, thought he would be shooting scenes that he and his family would look back on with fondness in future years. He certainly did not foresee that the first footage he shot, before the camera even left
title: At Crown Hts. Trial, Taped Images of Chaos

body: A retired police detective testified yesterday that Lemrick Nelson Jr. had confessed to him that he had stabbed a Hasidic Jew who was killed during the 1991 racial violence in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. The testimony by the former detective, Edward Brown, came at the trial of Mr. Nelson and another man, Charles Price, in United States District Court
title: Detective Describes Crown Hts. Confession

Dr. Mary Ann Chiasson said that she could not give a conclusive reason for the decline, but that the most likely
title: Metro Digest

Clasping placards suggesting that the lives they risk for the city were
title: New York Police, Seeking Raises, Assail Mayor They Once Backed

title: Agitator Tied Directly to Crown Hts. Attack

title: Arson Kills 2 Employees In a Store In Brooklyn

title: Violent Night In Crown Hts. Is Recalled

title: Defense Teams Square Off In Joint Crown Heights Trial

title: Brooklyn Mother Wins Millions, Just in Time

title: METRO DIGEST

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

title: A Tale of Two Districts

body: SIX street sweepers trudged along Brooklyn Avenue in Crown Heights, where the morning sunshine hardly softened the sting of piercing gusts. Their Day-Glo orange vests, standard issue for workfare cleaning crews, caught Sharon Bush's eye. Where, she asked them, were the coats, boots or thermal gloves they should have got to shield them against
title: Acorn Yearns To Grow Tall, Via Workfare

title: 4 Students Shot Near a School In Brooklyn

body: NEW YORK Charting Immigration Trends European immigration to New York City surged in the 1990's to levels unseen since the 1960's. The Dominican Republic became more entrenched as the city's largest source of immigrants. And more than 4 in every 10 births were to immigrants. These are among the trends to emerge from a portrait of the 563,000 legal
title: Metro Digest

body: More than five years after violence rocked Crown Heights, Brooklyn, leaving a wake of politically volatile recrimination, two black men are to go on trial tomorrow on charges of violating the civil rights of a Hasidic scholar fatally stabbed during the outbreak. Up to 250 prospective jurors will arrive in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to fill
title: Jury Selection Is to Begin In '91 Crown Heights Case

body: It has been more than five years since violence rocked Crown Heights, Brooklyn. And a jury had earlier acquitted a black man accused of stabbing a Hasidic scholar to death in the outbreak. Now that suspect and another man go on trial tomorrow on charges of violating the scholar's civil rights. Up to 250 prospective jurors will arrive in Federal
title: Crown Heights Case Heads Back to Court

body: To the Editor: ''Teachers Who Fail'' (editorial, Dec. 28) described better procedures for weeding out failing teachers in New York City schools but did not address how to attract and keep good teachers. I entered the school system in 1994 as a teacher of English as a Second Language with no formal training in education and no curriculum to guide
title: One Who Got Away
